options: virtual seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
-learning about historical mass atrocities 
-learn about related international law
How to read and think about mass atrocities, genocide, international law, and international institutions that seek to respond to and prevent atrocities
History of Genocide and other mass atrocities, as well as how the international community has structured definitions and protocols for such atrocities.
I learned all about the history, politics, and law of genocide and other mass atrocities

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Incredible course, very interesting subject material and really enjoyed the simulation-based approach combined with memo writing.
Very interesting class, and role-plays allowed us to experience some of issues of international cooperation and the different interests between members of the UN Security Council.

I felt the course did a great job providing an overview of several complex historical and modern mass atrocities that was both accessible and did not sacrifice depth of understanding. The only challenges I noticed were those of time, and I would have appreciated a little more discussion following the simulation exercises in particular. However this was overall a really interesting and engaging course.

Strengths: nice Professor and interesting topic. Small size made the simulations very good.  Cool guest speaker too
Weaknesses: no rubric for the briefs so he graded them pretty harshly

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Worked very well. Professor was responsive and adaptive to changing conditions.
Zoom worked well for the seminar. Professor would occasionally show videos that would lag a bit but otherwise could be viewed through screen sharing.
I liked the simulations on zoom

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes. This course is excellent by the measure of how informative and helpful it is for students to approach a wide range of topics in genocide and mass atrocity studies.
If you are interested in international relations or mass atrocities and human rights, this class is very good.

I would strongly recommend this course to anyone interested in international law, human rights, genocide prevention, or any related field. The course does a great job capturing the international politics that are implicated in massive abuses of human dignity. Furthermore, Professor Simon does a good job steering discussions towards more in-depth explorations of how to stop atrocities that goes beyond just saying there should have been military intervention. This is not something I had encountered in many of my other classes and I was really grateful for that aspect of this course.

Yes!  Professor Simon is so nice and a good guy to get to know (especially if youre a political science major). Its also such an important topic nowadays, so I definitely recommend if youre at all interested in human rights.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Zoom discussion seminars and occasionally role-plays.
Also had in person office hours
